loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy palm nuts

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang N., 38, lives in Battambang Province and earns a low income. She is a good and determined mother who tries to feed her four children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a bicycle repairman.
Neang N. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, she goes to a place that is full of fisherman to buy fish in bulk. Then she hurries to the market, where she sells the fish retail. Neang N. is requesting a loan to purchase an old vehicle to transport the fish. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will build a small pigpen where she plans to raise a few pigs for extra revenue.

loans.use: To purchase an old vehicle for transportation

loans.name: Tumurchudur

texts.en:
Tumurchudur B., aged 26, lives with his wife and two-year-old daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, located in a small yard that they rent. 
Tumurchudur operates a wooden furniture manufacturing business in his own small workshop. He runs the business with his wife's help. He started his business with capital of 100,000 MNT after participating in a wooden products manufacturing training course in 2002. Since that time, Tumurchudur has been operating his business successfully and today has increased his capital to a level exceeding 2,900,000 MNT. His business earnings have enabled him to expand his business and purchase new equipment to manufacture his products. 
Tumurchudur is a very hardworking person and prides himself on creating a variety of products that his customers will like. He is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase timber and to transport his products to other provinces to sell.

loans.use: To purchase timber and a GAZ truck to transport his products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy palm nuts

loans.name: Yang

texts.en: Yang R., 64, sells various kinds of vegetables in the local market, and earns approximately $3 profit a day. Besides her current work, she also takes time to grow a rice crop. She is married to Leum Ngorm, aged 58, who shares responsibility for his family by working as an ox-trader. Yang R. has a child who is single, and two other children who are now married and live away from home. All of them are employed in various jobs. Yang R. is taking out her first loan to buy a cow to raise to produce a baby and to use to plow her farmland.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Tugalhuu

texts.en:
Tugalhuu B. is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional nomadic tent called a ger in a small yard that they rent. His oldest son, Davaasuren, attends a local primary school, and his youngest, Temuujin, will soon begin school.
Tugalhuu operates a bread-making business in his town with the help of his wife. They sell the bread that they produce to small grocery shops and service centers throughout their local area. He started his business in 2009 with working capital of 100,000 MNT and has grown his business successfully in a short time. In only a year, his working capital has increased to a level exceeding 300,000 MNT.
Tugalhuu's family and business are both very important to him. One day, he hopes to purchase a yard for his family to live in. He is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to purchase flour in bulk to make bread to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To purchase flour in bulk to make bread

loans.name: Lingueres Keur Salla Group

texts.fr: Le groupe lingueres de keur salla groupe de quatre (4) vendeuses de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis ciq (5) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de deux cent francs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.
texts.en:
The “Lingueres de Keur Salla” group consists of four retailers of vegetables and condiments from a neighbourhood market in the town of Mbour. This group was created five years ago, requiring that daily fees of 200 CFA be collected from each member and given to one of the members on a rotating basis. This sum is then used in the commercial activities to bolster the group’s working capital. As these daily fees proved insufficient to support the working capital, the group requested a loan. Most group members have left their home village to settle in town and earn enough to feed their families.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: commercial usage

loans.name: Bathuyag

texts.en: Bathuyag J. lives with his wife and four-year-old son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife, Dolgorsuren, is a salesperson in a general store. During the day, Bathuyag operates a public transport business using his own micro-bus. He transports people between various districts of the city. Over the years, J. has become a very experienced driver who is known and trusted by his many customers. Bathuyag hopes to continue his business successfully in the future and sees many opportunities to grow his business. He hopes to refurbish his micro-bus soon. Bathuyag is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to build a house for his family.

loans.use: To purchase some household goods for his family needs

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is divorced with five children and all her children go to school. The family lives in a three-room house and they have access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and utility bills. She owns a stall at her home in Kawempe selling bananas and buys these bananas from delivery vans, which get them from the villages. She has been in this business for a long time. Florence wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. Besides this banana business, she is also a poultry farmer and even owns rental rooms.  Her customers are the community around her home. Florence works seven days a week. Her business challenges are seasonal (like high banana prices) and defaulters. She aspires to educate her children up to university and to start going to Masaka for bananas. She joined MCDT because it was the first MFI to reach out to poor women.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Amarbayasgalan

texts.en:
Amarbayasgalan C., aged 46, lives with her two children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a small house that they own. Both her son and daughter, aged 19 and 6, attend local schools.
Currently, Amarbayasgalan operates a tailoring business in her town. She started her business in 2006, with working capital of 350,000 MNT, after purchasing a sewing machine. Over the years, she has built a loyal customer base that appreciates her high quality products and good service. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,300,000 MNT. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a house and yard for her family.
Amarbayasgalan is an honest person and has much hope for the future. Currently, with the graduation season underway, she hopes to use her loan to take advantage of increased demand for her tailored products. Her dream is to one day have her own sewing workshop. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and other materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: commercial activity

loans.name: Binèfou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Binèfou D.   est un homme marié de 50 ans et monogame qui vit à Kalakan,  avec ses  dix enfants, dans l’un des villages de la Préfecture de  Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali.
Monsieur Binèfou  D. a dix huit ans d’expérience dans les activités d’achat et de vente de bétails.
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance   Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui, il est à son troisième  cycle de prêt individuel, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents. 
Il  compte acheter des bœufs dans la Préfecture de Kolondièba et effectuer sa vente au comptant, souvent à crédit à Nièna et parfois dans son village.   
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de 50000 FCFA par mois.  Le bénéfice  sera investi dans l’entreprise.
Dans l’avenir Monsieur D. compte aller vendre ses animaux dans les pays voisins pour avoir beaucoup de bénéfice.
texts.en:
Mr. Binèfou D., 50, married and monogamous, lives in Kalakan, with his 10 children, in one of the villages of the prefecture of Kolondièba in the third administrative region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Binèfou D. has 18 years' experience in buying and selling livestock. To increase his capital, he joined the credit program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his third individual loan, after having correctly reimbursed the two preceding ones. He intends to buy cattle in the prefecture of Kolondièba paying cash, or often on credit in Nièna, and sometimes in his own village. He hopes to make a monthly profit of 50,000 F CFA. The profit will be reinvested in his business. In the future, Mr. D. intends to go and sell animals in neighboring countries so as to have a lot of profit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock for resale

loans.name: Lingueres Fallokh Serere Group

texts.fr: Le groupe lingueres de FALLOKH SERERE groupe de cinq (5) vendeuses de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis cinq (5) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de deux cent francs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.
texts.en:
The “Lingueres de Fallokh Serere” group consists of five retailers of vegetables and condiments from a neighbourhood market in the town of Mbour. This group was created five years ago, requiring that daily fees of 200 CFA be collected from each member and given to one of the members on a rotating basis. This sum is then used in the commercial activities to bolster the group’s working capital. As these daily fees proved insufficient to support the working capital, the group requested a loan. Most group members have left their home village to settle in town and earn enough to feed their families.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: commercial activity

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en: Oliver is married with eight children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Oliver owns a stall in Ntinda Kigowa on the out skirts of Kampala, selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for 15 years.  She wants to use this loan to buy more fruits and vegetables from Nakawa market, like mangoes. oranges, tomatoes and cabbages.  She works six days a week.  Her business challenge is transportation of perishable fruits from Nakawa to Ntinda. Oliver uses public transport to and from shopping. The family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Djibril

texts.fr:
Monsieur Djibril C.  est un homme marié de 29ans qui est polygame. Il vit   avec ses épouses et ses deux  enfants à Mena,  un des villages de la Préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali. 
Monsieur Djibril fait le commerce d’articles divers. Sa boutique  se trouve à son domicile.
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier cycle de prêt. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, dix 50kg  de sucre, un carton de cigarettes, deux cartons de thé, quelques sacs de céréales et des conserves.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 60.000FCFA par mois.
Le bénéfice  servira à payer de la nourriture et sera investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Djibril C., 29, is married and polygamous. He lives with his spouses and his two children in Mena, one of the villages of the prefecture of Kolondièba in the third administrative region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Djibril sells various items, and his shop is located in his house. To grow his working capital, he joined the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his first loan. With this loan, he intends to buy 50 kg of sugar, a carton of cigarettes, 2 cartons of tea, several sacks of cereals, and some tinned goods. He expects to make a profit of 60,000 F CFA each month. His profit will be used to pay for food for the family and invested back into the business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy palm nuts

loans.name: Moctar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Moctar Koné  est un homme marié de 29 ans qui vit dans une famille monogame avec ses deux  enfants et son épouse dans le quartier Ouest de Kolondièba dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
 Monsieur Moctar fait comme activité génératrice de revenu l’achat  stockage vente de céréales depuis maintenant plusieurs années.
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté,  il adhéra au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso en optant pour le prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales. Il est à son quatrième cycle après avoir bien remboursés les trois prêts précédents.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte avoir 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre à la période où le cours est plus élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne sur le marché de Kolondièba les jours de foire et revendra aux grossistes venant de Sikasso et Bamako.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  60.000  FCFA 
Il compte faire prospérer son commerce en faisant varier ses articles pour réaliser un chiffre d’affaire plus élevé dans les jours à venir. Le bénéfice  sera  investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Moctar Koné, 29, is married and lives in a monogamous family with his two children and his wife, in the West district of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Moctar stocks and resells cereals to earn his living and has been doing this for several years. Wishing to lift himself out of poverty, he joined the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso, opting for an individual loan for stocking and selling cereals. He is on his fourth loan, after having reimbursed the three preceding loans. With this new loan, he intends to buy 400 kg of peanuts and 1000 kg of millet which he will stockpile for sale at the period where the price is higher. He buys his grains at the market of Kolondièba on market days and sells to wholesalers coming from Sikasso and Bamako. He hopes to make an average monthly profit of 60,000 F CFA. He intends to make his business prosper by varying the items he sells so as to make more sales in the days to come. His profit will be reinvested in his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals to stockpile for resale

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina is the mother of two children. Her husband is a simple worker and does not earn that much. To help her husband, Zarina started cooking confectionery and selling it at the market. But her cakes were so tasty that customers started to come to her house to order them. Now, since Zarina has many loyal customers, she wants to buy some good cooking equipment to produce more cakes. In this way, she hopes to improve her standard of living.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cooking equipment

loans.name: Abed Alateef

texts.en:
Abed Alateef A. M. is a 19-year-old young man from Jenin. Abed Alateef started working in an early age. He bought a small truck and started distributing fruits and vegetables. He has become a reliable vendor to many shops in the city. Because he is a very active and happy person, everyone wants to deal with him.

Abed Alateef took a $500 loan from FATEN to pay the last payment of the truck he purchased. Abed Alateef is now very relieved that he owns the truck and all benefits of his business will be his.

In the photograph, Abed Alateef sits in FATEN's office.

loans.use: To pay for his business truck

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Madame Kadiatou Konaté   est une femme mariée de 27 ans  qui vit avec ses 5 enfants et son mari dans une famille monogame, à Fakola, un des villages de la Préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali.
Kadiatou fait essentiellement le commerce de tissus, de vêtements et de pagnes wax. Son lieu de vente  se trouve au marché de Fakola.
Pour augmenter son capital elle adhère au programme  crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier  prêt individuel. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter des tissus traditionnels en Côte-d’Ivoire un pays voisin du Mali.  Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. La vente  se fait au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 50.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé dans l’achat de céréales pour la nourriture de la famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadiatou Konaté is a married woman, 27 years of age, who lives with her five children and her husband in a monogamous family in Fakola, a village in the Kolondièba prefecture in the third administrative region (Sikasso) of Mali. Kadiatou’s main business activity is selling fabrics, clothing and was “pagnes” [traditional fabrics for wrap clothing]. She has a vendor spot at the Fakola market. In order to bolster her business capital, she has joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program; this would be her first individual loan. Wit this loan, she plans to purchase traditional fabrics in Côte-d’Ivoire, a country neighboring Mali. Her customer base is composed of both men and women. She sells for cash and on credit. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 50,000 West African francs, which will be used toward purchasing cereals to feed her family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing traditional fabrics [for resale]

loans.name: Complex Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Janet is a 46-year-old woman with four children.  Janet describes herself as a visionary.  For the past 4 years, Janet has operated a retail business selling eggs and clothing.  She will use the loan to buy crates of eggs and clothes.  Janet’s future goals include expanding her business and building a house for her family.  She would also like to help her children acquire higher education.  

Janet is currently the leader of the group called 'Complex'. The group has 14 female members.  The other group members are engaged in trades such as selling 'kente' cloth, a traditional Ghanaian cloth usually worn during traditional occasions. They may sell clothes or sell fish. They plan to use the loan to purchase various inventory items to grow their businesses

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothes and crates of eggs for resale

loans.name: Lingueres De Santhie Group

texts.fr: Le groupe lingueres de SANTHIE groupe de cinq (5) vendeuses de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis cinq (5) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de deux cent francs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.

This sum is then used in the commercial activities to bolster the group’s working capital. As these daily fees proved insufficient to support the working capital, the group requested a loan. Most group members have left their home village to settle in town and earn enough to feed their families.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: commercial activity

loans.name: Kabudsor

texts.en:
S. Kabudsor is a hardworking married woman who has three children. For the past 14 years, Kabudsor has dedicated herself to selling office supplies. She started her business when her husband's contract with a construction company ended. Without her husband’s income, bills started to pile up so Kabudsor decided to generate her own income to try to fill the gap. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Kabudsor is now requesting a loan of 10,000 TJS to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. This is an important matter for her family's well-being. Please help Kabudsor’s business to grow.

More about Tajikistan

It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase office supplies for resale

loans.name: Karim

texts.fr:
Monsieur Karim Konaté est un homme marié de 38 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec ses  femmes et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle dans son village N’godiarrala.  N’godiarrala est un village de la sous-préfecture de Fakola, préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région(Sikasso) de la  République  Mali.
Ayant abandonné l’école depuis le premier cycle fondamental (système éducatif Malien), Monsieur  Konaté a tenté plusieurs activités économiques telles la vente d’habits, de chaussures, de tasses, mais finit par opter pour l’achat vente de céréales, appris auprès d’un de ses grand frères. Il est à sa dixième année d’expérience dans cette activité et dispose d’un magasin de vente.
Monsieur Konaté est à son quatrième prêt individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés .
Il veut acheter avec ce prêt, 1000kg de maïs, 500kg d’arachide et 500kg de mil et effectue sa vente à clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Konaté compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 .000FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir son magasin et  assurer les dépenses de la famille (santé,scolaire,.nourriture).
texts.en:
Mr. Karim Konaté is a married man of 38 and the father of three children. He lives with his wives and children in a big traditional family in his village of N’godiarrala, a village in the county of Fakola, prefecture of Kolondièba, in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Having left off at the end of basic school (Malian education system,) Mr. Konaté tried out several money-earning activities such as selling clothing, shoes, dishes, but finally opted for buying and reselling cereals, which he learned how to do from his older brothers. He has an experience of 10 years now and owns his own shop. Mr. Konaté is on his fourth individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso. All his preceding loans were correctly reimbursed. He wants to use this loan to buy 1000 kg of maize, 500 kg of peanuts, and 500 kg of millet. He sells to a clientele composed of both retailers and individual consumers. With this loan, Mr. Konaté expects to make a monthly profit of 75,000 F CFA. He proposes to use this profit to enlarge his store and to cover family expenses (health, school fees, food).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy palm nuts

loans.name: Obare

texts.en:
E. is 27 years old and single. He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for over eight years and his main products are milk, maize and tomatoes, which he sells to the local market. He relies solely on his farming activities to cater for his needs.
E. has a good record with Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, after successfully completing his loan of 30,000 KES. He has requested this loan from Juhudi for 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. Through this loan, he will be able to increase his sources of income through the sale of milk. His major challenges in farming are a lack of a proper market for his products and a poor road network to access the market.
He hopes to expand his dairy farming by purchasing four quality dairy cows producing at least 20 litres of milk each per day. He is requesting that Juhudi continue to support him financially.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is married with two children and both her children go to school.  She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall selling second hand shoes and sells to all categories of people at retail and at wholesale.  She incurs transport costs to and from home and buys her shoes from the very place where she works.  Harriet wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand shoes.  She has been doing this business for eight years.  She pays monthly market dues of 50,000/=.  Harriet works six days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality (the rainy season because she works from an open place) and defaulters.  She aspires to go to Mombasa for shoes.  She decided to work with MCDT because it was charging low interest. She resides in and owns a three-room house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand shoes

loans.name: Madou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Madou Sangaré est un homme marié de 28ans qui vit dans une famille monogame avec  ses deux enfants et son épouse dans le quartier N’gola  dans la  ville de  Fakola  (Sous-préfecture) dans la   troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du Mali. 
Monsieur Madou  Sangaré est éleveur, boucher et vendeur de bétails depuis maintenant huit ans.
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Il  compte acheter, des bœufs dans la Sous-préfecture de Fakola et environnants.  La vente se fait au comptant à Nièna et à  Bougouni.   
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui servira à payer les frais de santé, de nourriture et le reste sera investir dans l’entreprise.
Il ambitionne acheter un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Madou Sangaré is a 28-year-old married man, living in a monogamous household with his wife and two children in the N’gola borough of the Fakola Sous-Préfecture, in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Maou Sandgaré has been raising cattle for the past eight years. He also butchers and sells the cattle. To increase his working capital he joined the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan programme, and is now requesting hs first loan. He intends to buy oxen in the Fakola Sous-Prefecture and the surrounding area. He conducts his sales against cash in Nièna and Bougouni. He hopes to attain monthly earnings of 75,000 FCFA which will be used to pay medical bills and food, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business. His ambition is to buy a plot of land to build a house.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cattle

loans.name: Faustino

texts.en:
Faustino A. T. was born 42 years ago in Mandia, in the Manica province of Mozambique. He is still pursuing secondary school studies, at the moment 10th grade. He still has two more grades to finish secondary. He lives with his partner and has a child with her. He also has two children in his home town from a previous relationship.

Faustino supports his child, his wife, a younger brother, a nephew and a niece. His son, brother and niece go to school; his nephew will start going in the near future.

Faustino left his hometown to come to Maputo province in 1994 when he was transferred by the army. He has worked in the army since 1987 as a naval mechanic. He learned this job from a British cooperation project in 1989 in Zambezia, a northern province.

Faustino is asking for a loan to keep constructing and improving the house he owns, where he lives with his family. Specifically, with the money from Kiva he will buy an electric pulley to extract water from the well on his property, as you can see in the photo.

This is Faustino’s third loan with Hluvuku. The previous loans were also used to help improve his house. He dreams of buying a car one day when he finishes improving and developing his house.

loans.use: To buy an electric pulley for the well at his home

loans.name: Tabon

texts.en: A. Tabon is the 44-year-old widowed mother of four children. She has been very supportive of her children since she became a single parent. Tabon has sold children’s clothes at her local market for the past six years. Because of this, she will be able to pay for her children to finish school. With low capital, Tabon is not able to buy larger quantities of clothes to sell. She would like to use the loan to buy more bales of clothes that come with variety to increase her stock. She hopes to raise enough income to enable all of her children to finish school. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes to increase her stock

loans.name: Noutèné

texts.fr:
Madame Noutèné Sangaré  est une femme mariée de 38 ans qui vit dans une famille polygame  avec son mari, ses coépouses et leurs enfants à Siana, un des villages de la préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali. 
Noutèné fait de la restauration il y’ a des années. Son  restaurant se trouve au bord de la route qui traverse son village. Elle est très fréquentée et appréciée des résidants et passants.
Pour augmenter son capital elle adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier  prêt individuel. 
Noutèné a fait les prêts solidaires et  de campagnes qui ont été tous correctement remboursés
Avec ce prêt individuel elle compte acheter,  500kg de riz, des condiments alimentaires et divers articles. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes et sa vente  se fait essentiellement  au comptant.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 75.000 FCFA par mois qui sera réinvesti dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Noutèné Sangaré is a married woman who is 38 years old. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, his other wives and their children, in Siana, one of the villages in the prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Noutèné has been active in the restauration business for years. Her restaurant is on the side of the road which crosses her village. Her restaurant is used a lot and very much appreciated by both residents of the village and passers-by. In order to increase her capital, Noutèné joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and is on her first individual loan with the institution. She has had group loans and farming loans in the past, all of which have been repaid on time. With this individual loan she is planning on buying 500kg of rice, condiments and other miscellaneous products. Her customer base is made up of men and women and her sales are made essentially for cash. She expects to make a monthly profit of 75,000FCFA which will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of restauration ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Lingueres Keur Madiagne 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe lingueres de keur MAD. 2 groupe de cinq (5) vendeuses de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis cinq (5) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de deux cent francs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.
texts.en:
The "Lingueres Keur MaD. 2" group consists of 5 sales women who sell vegetables and condiments at the neighborhood market in the city of Mbour. Created 5 years ago this group charges its members 200 CFA francs a day as a membership fee. This money is then loaned to various members of the group. This fund is used as the working capital for the group. As there is insufficient working capital to meet the needs of the group, they have decided to make a loan. Most of the group members have moved from their village to the city to be able to feed their families.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To provide business working capital

loans.name: Gilberto

texts.en:
Gilberto C. was born in Maputo city, the capital of Mozambique, in 1971 and has never lived anywhere else. He studied till 8th grade and then emigrated to neighboring south Africa to learn a living. There he learnt how to build and paint ceilings, although he has not done that any more in a long time.

Gilberto lives with his partner and has two children with her, aged 7 and 4. The eldest goes to school and the youngest will go soon. He also supports one sister of his who lives nearby.

Gilberto had been working for a while as a car painter till, in 2004, he opened a hairdresser's nearby which he now runs. He has a couple of employees and makes an income of about 500 meticals per day.

Gilberto is asking for a loan to start up a little grocery business within his property, at a stall next to his house that he shows in the photo and is about to finish. With the money from Kiva he is going to buy rice, milk, sugar and other food products to sell there with the help of his wife.

This is Gilberto’s third loan from Hluvuku, Kiva´s partner in Mozambique. The first one was also to start a grocery business but that did not work out; the second was used to perform construction work on his property.

Gilberto dreams of starting other businesses nearby if things go well. For example, he names an off-license shop.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, milk, beverages and other food products for his shop

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane Traoré  est un homme marié de 29ans monogame, qui vit   avec ses deux  enfants et leur mère à Fakola, un des villages de la préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali.
Monsieur Souleymane fait le commerce de carburants, de lubrifiants et de quelques articles divers (liquides de freins, liquide refroidisseurs de radiateurs...). 
Pour augmenter son capital et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus grande, il adhère au programme  crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui,  il est à son troisième  cycle de prêt, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux prêts précédents. Son lieu de vente  se trouve au marché de Fakola, où il est très sollicité et apprécié.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, 10 fûts d’essences ordinaires. Il s’approvisionne à Guèya  en Côte-D’Ivoire, un pays frontalier de la république du Mali, auprès des grossistes et revend en détail et au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 90.000 FCFA par mois qui servira à payer  de la nourriture et  le reste sera réinvesti dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane Traoré is a married man who is 29 years old and monogamous. He lives with his two children and their mother in Fakola, one of the villages in the prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Souleymane has a business trading in fuel, lubrification oil and other miscellaneous items (brake liquid, cooling liquid for radiators...). In order to increase his capital and satisfy his growing customer base more readily, he joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and is now on his third loan cycle with the institution. He repaid the previous two loans on time. He sells his products at the market in Fakola, where he is in great demand and much appreciated. With this loan he is planning on buying 10 barrels of ordinary petrol. He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Guèya in the Ivory Coast, a country which borders on Mali. He resells on a retail basis for cash and rarely on credit to a very diverse customer base. He is expecting to make a monthly profit of 90,000FCFA which will be used to pay for food and to reinvest in his business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fuel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Heredon Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Hérèdon (cinq femmes mariées dont deux dans des familles polygames) ont en moyenne 28 ans, 4 enfants et résident toutes dans le quartier N’gola  de Fakola l’une des Sous préfecture de Sikasso (3ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et font toutes la restauration sauf Chata Koné, un des membres du groupe qui excelle plutôt dans la vente de pâtes d’arachides. Elles achète les grains d’arachides et la transforme en pâtes.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de diversifier les articles à vendre, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé le premier. 
Chata Koné compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 100kgs de grains d’arachides auprès des grossistes au marché de Fakola. Chata effectue sa vente en ambulant dans les quartiers, à domicile et au marché de Fakola, à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes qui achètent au comptant et parfois à crédit. 
Chata, à l’instar des autres membres du groupe, espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7900FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et prendre en charge les petits besoins de la famille en condiments. 
Les femmes du groupe (majoritairement des restauratrices) ont pour ambition d’acheter  chacune un réfrigérateur pour produire de la glace et les jus de fruits.
texts.en:
The women of the Heredon loan group ( five married women including two women of polygamous families) are an average of 24 years of age, with two children. They live in the N'gola neighborhood of Fakola, a sub-district of Sikasso, the third administrative region in Mali. They know each other as neighbors and are all in the restaurant business with the exception of Chata Koné, who is a group member who excells at the sale of peanut butter. She buys bulks peanuts and prepares the peanut butter paste herself. To increase their operating capital and provide a greater variety of goods to sell, theydecided to become associated with Soro Yiriwaso with who they are now taking out their second group loan, having duly repaid their first loan. Chata Koné plans to use the loan to buy 100 kgs of peanuts from the wholesalers in Fakola. Chata hawks her product in the neighborhood around Fakola, to a clientel made up generally of women, who buy for cash or occasionally credit. Chata hopes to earn an average monthly income of 7900 francs CFA and like the other members of the group, will use the income to make her loan payments and meet the basic needs of her family. The women of the group who are in the restaurant business each want to purchase a refrigerator to make ice and to store fruit drinks.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies of peanuts to make peanut butter

loans.name: Lameck

texts.en:
Lameck is 34 years old and married with two children, 6 and 7 years old. Both of the children are attending school.

Lameck is a farmer in Western Kenya near Kisii town. He has been practicing mixed farming for twelve years and employs one person from the community to assist on the farm. His main products are maize, milk and beans which he sells to the local market. He is also a primary school teacher.

Lameck has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo after he successfully completed his second loan of KES 50,000. He has requested this KES 50,000 loan from Juhudi to purchase a dairy cow. The income from this loan will enable him to take his children to a good school and provide enough milk for domestic consumption. His main challenges are lack of transport and the high cost of production.

In future, Lameck would like to set up a cereal bank in his region. He is grateful to Juhudi for being efficient and fast in loan processing.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka Konaté  est un homme marié de 32 ans et père de trois enfants qui vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie dans la ville de Fakola, préfecture de Kolondièba dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, il adhéra au programme  de prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son troisième prêt individuel, tous les deux prêts antérieurs ont été remboursés sans aucune difficulté.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre à la période où le cours sera plus  élevé.
Il s’approvisionne sur le marché de Fakola les jours de foire auprès des producteurs et effectue sa vente généralement à Bamako (capitale du Mali) aux revendeurs et à quelques consommateurs. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000 FCFA soit 75.000FCFA  trimestriellement.
Il compte faire prospérer son commerce en faisant varier ses articles pour réaliser un chiffre d’affaire plus élevé dans les jours à venir. Le bénéfice prendra en charge les frais scolaire,  de santé,  de nourriture et le reste sera  réinvesti dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Konaté, 32, is married and the father of three children. He lives in a big traditional, extended family in the town of Fakola, prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. In order to better uplift himself out of poverty, he joined the individual loan program for stocking and selling cereals of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his third individual loan, both preceding loans having been reimbursed with no difficulty. With this loan he is intending to buy 400 kg of peanuts and 1000 kg of millet which he will warehouse so as to sell them when the price is higher. He buys his supplies in the market of Fakola, on weekly marketdays from the producers, and generally sells his goods in Bamako (capital of Mali) to retailers and some consumers. He hopes to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 F CFA or 75,000 F CFA per quarter. He hopes to make his business more prosperous by varying his inventory so as to have a greater turnover in future. The profit will cover school fees, health expenses, and food, with any remainder reinvested into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals to stockpile for resale

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is now divorced with six children and all her children go to school. Margaret takes care of additional family members like her old parents and her sister's children. Formerly Margaret was selling second hand clothes but she changed her business enterprise to making envelopes and paper bags. She buys her raw materials from Nkrumah Road shops in Kampala city and uses public transport to and from buying these raw materials. She has been doing this business for the last three months. Margaret is now proud of this business.  Besides this business, she doesn’t have any other side business.  She wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials like papers and glue.  She aspires to have a shop where she can display and sell her products. She joined MCDT because it was charging low interest.  Margret owns and resides in a four-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more  raw materials like papers and glue

loans.name: Hikmatullo

texts.en: N. Hikmatullo is 27 years old and is married with three children. Five years ago he started his business selling cell phones. He believes that this business is profitable and the generated income allows him to support his family. However, Hikmatullo thinks that it is expensive to purchase cell phones locally and it will save money for him if he purchases the goods in China. With this purpose in mind, he requests a loan of 1,800 USD. This being his second loan, Hikmatullo is grateful to all supporting him and promises to repay the loan promptly. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones from China to sell

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is a 30-year-old married man who is blessed with a two-year-old child. He has been running a cafeteria for five years and employs three people. His business is located near an open-air market and therefore he has many customers. He mainly prepares beef stew in his cafeteria but also makes other types of food.

Mathew has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 to buy timber and nails for renovating his business premise, chairs for his cafeteria, and three bulls to slaughter. He dreams of having a butcher shop and a restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To buy timber, nails and chairs plus three bulls to slaughter

loans.name: Sahibou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Sahibou Koné  est un homme marié de 28 ans, sans enfant, qui vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Koko, un des quartiers de Fakola (une sous-préfecture) dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali. 
Sahibou fait  le commerce d’articles divers notamment l’achat vente de matériels électroniques depuis maintenant cinq ans. Son magasin se trouve au marché de Fakola.
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier  prêt individuel. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, dix radios cassette, deux téléviseurs, des cassettes vierges pour le repiquage  et d’autres divers articles électroniques. Il s’approvisionne auprès des forains venant de la Côte d’Ivoire et effectue sa vente, au comptant souvent à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée.   
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000 FCFA par mois qui sera essentiellement réinvesti dans l’entreprise et  dans les frais de  santé.
texts.en:
Mr. Sahibou Koné 28, is married without children, and lives in a big traditional family in Koko, a neighborhood of Fakola (a county) in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. Sahibou has been buying and selling various items, notably electronic goods, for the past five years. His store is at the open-air market of Fakola. To expand his working capital, he joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and he is on his first individual loan. With this loan he is intending to buy ten cassette radios, two televisions, some new cassettes for dubbing, and various other electronics goods. He buys his inventory from traveling salesmen who come from Côte d’Ivoire and he makes his sales for cash and often on credit to a varied and diverse clientele. He expects to make a monthly profit of 25,000 F CFA which will be essentially reinvested in his business and used to cover healthcare expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cassette radios and televisions

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a 24-year-old single man. He prepares and sells popcorn, eggs and sausages to earn a living. He has been in this business for two years and employs one person.

Isaac has been saving his money on a weekly basis with a group in Faulu Kenya. He joined this group so as to access finances easily. This is because the group members guarantee each other’s loans.

Isaac has requested a loan of Kes 15,000 to expand his business premises. He hopes to expand his business so as to improve his living standard.

loans.use: To expand his business premises

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 32 years old and is married with two children, 2 and 4 years old. His eldest child is attending school.

Paul is a dairy farmer in Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for five years and employs two people from the community. His main product is milk which he sells to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Litein town.

Before venturing into farming, Paul was operating a shop in the same area. His main challenges in farming are the poor transport network, fluctuations in the price of milk and lack of clean water.

Paul has requested this loan of KES 50,000 to construct a store for animal feed. This will minimize the time spent in looking for animal feed and provide a constant supply.

In the future, Paul would like to supply more milk and have pure breeds in the next five years.

loans.use: To construct a store for animal feed

loans.name: André

texts.en:
Andre Tome S. was born in the Mozambican Sofala province. He is 31 years old. He is in the process of finishing secondary school education. He is currently studying 11th grade out of a total of 12 grades. He is married and has three children, two twins aged two and a baby aged 3 months. None of them attend  school yet. He supports all of them and also sends money to help his family in the Sofala province.

He left his hometown to go to Maputo in 2001on his own. He is in the army and works in the training area. He is requesting a loan to buy a property with a business partner. He would like to refurbish it to make it habitable and be able to earn profit from it. He currently lives with his family in a rented house.

This is his second loan. With the first one he bought electrical appliances for his home. Getting the property ready once he buys it is going to take him a long time but he is looking forward to it.

He is in the picture next to the army barrack where he instructs future soldiers.

loans.use: To buy a house to refurbish

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 34 year old married woman,  blessed with three children who attend school.  She has been operating a retail shop for six years where she sells detergents.  She was previously employed as a teacher.  Since she joined the Mothers of Hope group in Faulu Kenya, she has been able to expand her business and employ more people.  This is because the group members previously guaranteed her a loan which she used to boost her business. 

She has requested for a loan of Kes. 60, 000 to buy raw materials for making detergents.  She dreams of owning real estate in the future.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making detergents

loans.name: Shamsiyakhon

texts.en:
R. Shamsiyakhon is 36 years old. She is married with 4 children. For the last 5 years she has been working in a beauty salon. In the salon she provides various services including hair styling, hair cutting, manicure, and the services of a cosmetologist. Her business is successful and generates a stable income for her family. Now Shamsiyakhon is planning to purchase cosmetology and other accessories for her beauty salon. Fror this purpose she is requesting a loan of $1700 US Dollars. Shamsiyakhon thanks all those supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.   
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase accessories for cosmetology in her beauty salon.

loans.name: Yusra

texts.en:
Yusra S. is a 52-year-old woman from Gaza City in Gaza Strip. Yusra and her son, Muhammad, and daughter, Fatima, started their disk jockey business two years ago. Yusra's four daughters and her son are college students, so she decided to start her own business to help her husband afford their household expenses.

Yusra bought the DJ equipment to provide music to wedding and parties in the city. Now that her number of clients is growing, she decided to rent a place and work from there, and to purchase modern machines. Therefore she took a $1500 loan from FATEN. The loan will increase her profits and number of clients they can serve, because they are now able to provide services to three clients at the same time.

Yusra and her son, Muhammad, appear in the photograph.

loans.use: Purchase DJ machines

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a 67 year old married man who has five children whose ages are between 26-39 years.  Only one of his children is still school.  He has been raising livestock for fourteen years.  He sells animal products such as milk and eggs and employs one person.  He has been a member of Faulu Kenya under a loan group where he saves his money weekly.  Being a member of the group, he can easily access loans from Faulu Kenya.  So far, he has taken two loans which he used to boost his business and has successfully repaid them.  He has requested for a loan of Kes. 70, 000 to buy a dairy cow and animal feed.  He hopes to own over ten cows in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and animal feed

loans.name: God Is King Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Adwoa is a 40-year-old woman.  She describes herself as honest.  She is married and has 4 children between 6 and 22 years old. For the past 4 years, Adwoa has operated a 'cold store' and she also sells sodas.  She will use the loan to purchase frozen fish and minerals (sodas). She hopes to eventually establish a big cold store and wholesale fish.

Adwoa is currently the leader of the trust bank group called 'God is King'.  There are 8 members in this group. Adwoa believes that she was elected the group leader because she is humble and diligent.  The other members of the group also trade in foodstuffs such plantains, yams and eggs.

loans.use: To purchase assorted fish, meat and soft drinks

loans.name: Khurshed

texts.en:
S. Khurshed is 44 years old. He sells household goods such as kettles, pails, basins and many others. He has been in this business for more than ten years. Because of his rich experience, Khurshed is able to choose goods that meet the requirements of his clients, whose tastes differ. The business is quite successful and generates the stable income that allows Khurshed to improve the living conditions of his family and to make his children happy. 

Today Khurshed is requesting 10,000 TJS. He is planning to use the loan to purchase new household goods to sell, thus enlarging the range of goods. With your help, this will be possible. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To enlarge the range of goods.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 45-year-old married man with five children, ages 10, 14, 16, 18 and 21 years.  He has been operating a cyber café for two years where he has employed two people.  He also raises chickens to earn extra income.  He was in construction work before he started his own business. 

He belongs to Faulu Kenya with a group of young entrepreneurs.  He has been an active member of Faulu Kenya and so far he has received two loans.  He has been allowed to take out another loan worth 80,000 KES because he has paid off his first two loans successfully.  

With this loan, he plans to buy stationery, one computer and to expand his business premises.  He hopes to own a computer college in the future.  He sees himself expanding his business and employing more people.

loans.use: To buy stationery, one computer and expand the business premises

loans.name: Sixto Ramón

texts.es:
El cliente es propietario de una despensa el cual lo maneja con su Señora. 
Es padre de 3 hijos menores de edad, estudiantes. Don Sixto decidió solicitar al crédito con el fin de adquirir mayor cantidad de panificados, lácteos, enlatados, fideos, arroz, harina, azúcar y otros para su stock lo cual aumentaría sus ventas y su nivel de ingreso familiar.
Sixto es una persona reconocida en el barrio por ser trabajador y por inculcar esos valores dentro de su familia, que con sacrificio ha sacado adelante.
El Cliente manifiesta su satisfacción por trabajar con la Fundación por el apoyo al desarrollo y crecimiento para su negocio.
texts.en:
Sixto is the owner of a food pantry that he manages with his wife. He is the father of three young children who are students. Don Sixto decided to request a loan so that he can acquire large quantities of baked goods, dairy products, canned goods, noodles, rice, flour, sugar, and other items for his inventory so that he can increase his sales and improve his family income. He is well-known in the neighborhood for being a hard worker and instilling values into his family. Through sacrifice he has been able to get ahead.

Sixto says he is pleased with the work of Fundación Paraguaya and its support for the growth and development of his business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Sulaina

texts.en: Sulaina is married with five children and all her children go to school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a ladies salon in Kisaasi Kulambiro zone.  She wants to use this loan to buy more cosmetics and hair extensions. She has been in this business for 15 years.  She buys these cosmetics from Kampala city shops and uses public transport to and from shopping. Sulaina goes shopping once a week.  She receives an average of 10 customers a day. Besides this salon business, she also sells second hand clothes.  She rents her business premises at 50,000/= per month.  Her customers are mainly women.  She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include seasonality, transportation and thieves.  She aspires to own a wholesale business. Sulaina joined MCDT because of low interest rates.  She resides in and owns a four-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent for her business and food.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and hair extensions

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 40 years old. She is married with three children, ages, 18, 15 and 12 years old. All her children are currently attending school. 

She is a farmer from western Kenya in Kitale town. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years. Her main products are tomatoes, bananas, maize and milk, which she sells to the local market. She depends solely on her farming activities to provide for her family. Her main challenges are poor means of transport, high production costs and the lack of enough capital for expansion.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 30,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income coming from this loan will improve her family's standard of living and also pay school fees for her children. She hopes to expand her dairy farming and get five good grade cows in the next five years.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ardan

texts.en:
Ardan D. Jillo is twenty-eight years old and married. They have one two-year-old child. 

Ardan's business is located in a business center called Mwingi, which is served by the Thika branch. He is engaged in selling mobile phone accessories to the local people. He has been in this business for five years and has managed to create employment for two people. He says this kind of business is very profitable. His major challenge is that at times he gets faulty accessories from the suppliers which leads to losses. 

He is using his loan of 20,000 KES to buy more accessories to expand his business. He hopes that one day he will make enough money to build a house for his family. He also hopes that some day his business will grow to a wholesale enterprise.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Arnulfo

texts.es:
El señor Arnulfo O. T. de profesion constructor de obra posee varios años en el rubro, vive en casa propia en el barrio Jardin de la cuidad de Encarnación, esta casado con la señora Estelvina Torres y tiene 3 hijos aun menores y en edad escolar.
El tiene trabajo constante ya que es constructor muy bueno y sus trabajos son muy bien realizados.
El solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción para hacer refracciones en su casa. Quiere reparar el techo con tejas nuevas, rebocar y pintar paredes.
texts.en:
Sr. Arnulfo O. T. is a professional builder with many years of experience. He lives in his own home in the neighborhood of Jardin in the city of Encarnación. He is married to Sra. Estelvina Torres and has three young children who are in school.

Arnulfo always has a steady flow of business since he is known as an excellent builder who produces quality work. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy construction materials for making repairs to his house. He wants to replace the tiles on the roof and plaster and paint the walls.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sand, cement, roofing tiles, and paint

loans.name: Aurora

texts.es:
La señora Aurora B. tiene 55 años D. edad, está casada desD. hace tiempo con el señor Pedro Benítez, viven en su propia casa que está situada en el barrio Arroyo Pora distrito D. Cambyreta.
La señora Aurora es comerciante, se dedica a la venta D. prendas D. vestir desD. hace más D. 5 años, tiene mucha clientela D. la zona donD. vive y también D. Posadas (Argentina), ya que va y viene todos los días para llevar sus mercaderías. 
 Su esposo el señor Pedro Benítez es contratista D. obras, se dedica a esta actividad desD. hace muchos años. 
 Mediante esta actividad ellos han podido mantener su hogar y salir adelante para solventar los gastos que se pudieran presentar. 
Ella hoy día esta solicitando el crédito para la compra D. mas mercaderías (camperas. Pantalones, suéter, buzos, jeans) ya que se acerca la temporada D. invierno y quiere renovar su stock.
texts.en:
Sra. Aurora B. is 55 years old and has been married for some time to Sr. Pedro Benítez. They live in their own home in the neighborhood of Arroyo Poro in Cambyreta District.

Aurora is a merchant who has been selling clothing for more than five years. She has many customers in the area where she lives. Aurora also has customers in Posadas, Argentina and travels there every day with her merchandise. Her husband, Pedro Benítez, is a building contractor and has worked for many years. Through their business activities, they have been able to maintain their household and succeed in covering all of their expenses.

At the moment, Aurora is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise (leather jackets, trousers, sweaters, sweatshirts, and jeans). With the winter season approaching, she wants to acquire more inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase winter clothing

loans.name: Faida Group

texts.fr:
Kavugho B. est conseillère du groupe de crédit  Faida, à l’ extrême, elle lève sa main sur la photo, âgée de 42 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants qui étudient. Son mari est portier de la résidence d’un Pasteur de l’église baptiste au Centre d’Afrique (CBCA). Kavugho B. est entrepreneur,vendeuse de friperie au marché central de Virunga. Pour accroitre ses revenus, Madame Kavugho B.  confectionne également les nappes, elle vend des services culinaires. Il ya 8 ans qu’elle vend les friperies. Elle a commence son activité avec son fonds propre, reçu de son beau frère, et une autre partie de bénéfice des petites commissions de vente objets de son voisin. Son capital initial était de 10$. 
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, elle compte acheter 1 ballon de friperie de chemises, 1/2 ballon des pentalons.
Le grand défi de Kavugho B. est que parfois, dans un ballon de friperie, elle retrouve des habits complètement usés et parfois déchirés. Dans un ballon de friperie, il y a parfois de futilité qu’on n’achète pas. C’est qui constitue une perte pour elle. Madame Kavugho B. souhaite atteindre un conteneur des ballons de friperie et devenir une grossiste de la ville. Cela serait faisable avec un capital de 5000$ qu’elle ambitionne dans les jours à venir. Pour sa famille, elle compte faire grandir ses enfants et le voir terminer tous les études dans les meilleures conditions.
Madame Kavugho B. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits permanents qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à  se prendre en charge et subvenir aux enfants. 
Ce groupe Faida est  composé de 22 membres femmes.
texts.en:
Kavugho B. is the president of the borrowing group Faida. She is standing on the far left and raising her hand in the photo. She is 42, married and the mother of seven children who are presently attending school. Her husband is the doorman at the residence of a Baptist church pastor at the Africa Center (CBCA). Kavugho B. sells used clothing at the central market of Virunga. To increase her income, Mrs. Kavugho B. also makes tablecloths and sells cooking sets. She has been selling used clothing for 8 years. She began her business with her own funds, which she had received from her brother-in-law, and also with money earned selling small items for her neighbor. Her initial working capital amounted to US$ 10. With the MFI Hekima loan, she is intending to buy one bale of used shirts and 1/2 bale of used pants. Her greatest challenge is that sometimes in a bale of used clothing, she finds items that are completely worn out and sometimes torn. In a bale of used clothing, there are sometimes useless items that no one will buy. This constitutes a loss for her. Mrs. Kavugho B. hopes to manage to get a container of bales of used clothing and become a wholesaler in her town. This would be possible with a loan of US$ 5000 which she hopes to obtain one of these days. As for her family, she intends to raise her children so as to see them finish their studies under the best possible conditions. Mrs. Kavugho B. thanks Hekima for the continued loans that she receives without any collateral, for it is due to these loans that she is able to support herself and her children. This Faida group consists of 22 members.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 1 bale of used shirts and 1/2 bale of used pants, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 38 years old. She is married with five children between the ages of 7 and 18 years old. All her children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last fifteen years. Her main products are maize, milk and eggs, which she sells locally. She also earns income from selling petrol and diesel fuel locally. Her main challenges are poultry diseases and stiff competition in the market. 

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 20,000 KES to start a poultry project after she successfully cleared her first loan of 15,000 KES. The extra income coming from this loan will enable her to pay school fees for her children. She hopes to expand her poultry project and increase the number of chickens over five years' time. 

She is grateful to Juhudi for empowering her economically.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: Benita

texts.es:
La señora Benita A. M. domiciliada en el barrio San Pedro de la cuidad de Encarnación se dedica a la compra y venta de animales porcinos, actividad que realiza con su conyugue el señor Eliodoro Vera.

Compras dichos animales los faenan y venden en la zona de Encarnación.
Ellos consiguen buena ganancia haciendo este trabajo, ademas pueden usar la carne para su alimentación.
Solicitan el préstamo para la compra de cerdos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Benita A. M. lives in the San Pedro neighborhood of the city Encarnación. She and her husband Eliodoro Vera have a business buying and selling pork products. The buy this animals and raise them to later sell them in Encarnación. They earn a good profit with this business, and they can also use the meat for food. They are applying for this loan to purchase more pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pigs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is 52 years old and married with five children between the ages of 15 and 30 years old. His youngest child is still attending school.

He is a farmer from Nyamira town in the South Rift region of Kenya. He has been farming for nineteen years and his main product is maize which he sells locally. He also owns some rental houses and earns income from the monthly rent that he collects. His main challenges in farming are limited agricultural land and capital for expansion.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 70,000 KES to purchase a cow after successfully completing his previous loan for 50,000 KES. The extra income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his child who is still in school.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 68 years old and the married father of seven children who are all adults. He is a farmer from Nyamira district in the South Rift region of Kenya.

He has been farming for forty years and his main products are milk and fruit, which he sells locally. He is also a cash crop farmer and earns income from tea that he sells to the local market. His main challenge in farming is limited agricultural land.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 20,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says this loan will help him get a good dairy cow that will produce enough milk to earn him more income. In the future, he would like to expand his farming activities by acquiring more dairy cows that will produce more milk to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kristo Nti Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
