loans.name: Francis Janett

texts.es:
Francis Janett P. Z. es una mujer trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora. Esta señora de 37 años tiene un pequeño bar el Colegio Paulo Cesto y distribuye ropa interior desde hace dos años negocios con el cual a mantenido a su familia y los cuales invertira el credito.

 Ella tiene tres hijos de 21, 13 y 10 años los cuales estudian, la mayor le ayuda en el sustento del hogar.
texts.en:
Francis Janett P. Z. is an enterprising and hardworking woman. This 37 year-old woman has a small bar "El Colegio Paulo Cesto," and she also has been distributing underwear for 2 years. With these businesses she supports her family; she will invest the proceeds of this loan in the businesses. She has 3 children aged 21, 13 and 10 years who are in school. The oldest helps her to support the household.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise (underwear) and to invest in her bar

loans.name: Ayda María

texts.es: Ayda María J. C. una mujer trabajadora, emprendedora y ersforzada quien desde hace diez años inicio su pequeño negocio que consistia en una pequeña y modesta venta la cual con el tiempo ha ido creciendo hasta lograr ser una pulperia.
texts.en:
Ayda María J. C. is a hard working entrepeneur who's had her own small business for the past 10 years. She owns a little grocery store and she hopes to in the future improve her sales and expand the business.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food and beverages for reselling

loans.name: Daniela Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Daniela es una mujer esforzada, trabajadora, con cinco hijos a quienes ha apoyado, junto con su esposo, el trabaja de albañil, no es un trabajo fijo, trabaja por cuenta propia. Desde hace varios años logro poner una pulpería en donde vende una variedad de productos. El cual ha sido su medio de entradas para ayudar a pagar los gastos  básicos.

Inicio con ayuda de su esposo con los ahorros de su trabajo, pensando también en que abecés no tiene trabajo y de esta manera se solventaría con su familia, en los gastos.

A través de los financiamientos ha logrado un crecimiento en su inventario y ha podido equilibrarse ya que abecés las ventas están bajas aunque no se deja de vender con este préstamo desea comprar granos básicos, golosinas, lácteos y cosmético para mejorar las ventas y la captación de clientes.
texts.en:
Daniela is a hard working woman, who has five children to support along with her husband. She works as a bricklayer, independently. She also owns a little grocery store where she sells a variety of products, and that has been her main source of income to cover basic expenses of her family. She started the business with the help of her husband, and hopes to one day support her family entirely by doing that. Because of the loans she got, she has been able to increase the amount of merchandise offered at her store and keep her inventory diverse with grains, pastries, dairy products as well as cosmetics, and attract more clients to her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food Products for Reselling

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita es una madre de familia de 30 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el distrito de Zaña, un distrito conocido a nivel regional por sus tradiciones y costumbres afro – peruanas, se encuentra ubicado a cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de dos años a la crianza y venta de animales, ella cría aves como patos, gallinas y también cría cuyes en unos corrales instalados en la parte posterior de su domicilio. Todos los martes viaja hacia una feria ubicada en el distrito de Cayaltí para vender sus animales, esta feria es muy frecuentada por personas de la costa y sierra de la zona por lo que la demanda por sus animales siempre es abundante.

Margarita distribuye su tiempo entre las labores propias del hogar y la crianza de sus animales, ella desea brindarles a sus animales una alimentación balanceada de modo que su calidad mejore y pueda percibir mas ganancias al momento de venderlos. Por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de1000 nuevos soles.

Margarita es una mujer bastante responsable y que siempre ve la manera de apoyar a su esposo para salir juntos adelante. En la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos le tienen bastante cariño y estima.
texts.en:
Margarita is a 30 year-old mother who lives with her husband and their children in the Zaña district, an area known at the regional level for its traditions and its Afro-Peruvian customs. It is located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For more than 2 years she has been raising and selling animals. She raises birds such as ducks and hens and she also raises guinea pigs in a pen that is installed behind her home. Each Tuesday she travels to a market located in the Cayaltí district to sell her animals. This market is very popular with people from the coast and the highlands in the area, so the demand for her animals is always high. Margarita divides her time between her household tasks and raising her animals. She wants to provide her animals with nutritious feed so that the quality of her animals will be better and she can earn more money when she sells them. For this reason she has requested for the first time a loan with Edpyme Alternativa for 1,000 Peruvian soles. Margarita is a very responsible woman who always finds a way to support her husband so that they can get ahead together. In the area where they live her neighbors and acquaintances have a lot of affection and esteem for her.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy nutritious feed to improve the quality of animals raised for sale

loans.name: Jeaneth Del Carmen

texts.es:
Doña Jeaneth es madre de tres hijos, de edad de 40 años, madre soltera que ha tenido que trabajar mucho para poder apoyar a sus hijos. Su trabajo es de conserje desde hace varios años.

 Poco a poco con ahorros y financiamiento esta logrando las mejoras de su casa. Con el crédito anterior compro materiales para la construcción de un cuarto para una mejor comodidad de sus hijos. Pero no logro comenzar por que hacia falta materiales es por eso con este crédito terminara de hacer las compras necesarias para comenzar hacer el cuarto al fondo del patio, que espera terminar con este financiamiento. Y poder gozar de estas mejoras.
texts.en:
Doña Jeaneth is a 40 year old single mother of three who has always had to work a lot to support her children. She's been working as a doorwoman for years. Slowly, with the help of loans, she has been able to improve her house and living conditions. With her previous loan she bought construction supplies to build an extra room and give her children more comfort. But she never started the construction because it was lacking certain materials, so she asked for another loan to buy the necessary supplies to start builidng the room.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita P. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Anecita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Anecita owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from processing and selling charcoal and wood-related products in the local community. Anecita is just starting this business.

In 2010, Anecita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Anecita is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anecita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Guillermo David

texts.es:
Guillermo tiene 18 años de edad, es soltero y no tiene hijos; vive junto a sus padres y abuelos en el distrito de Cayaltí, distrito agricola en donde se cultiva principalmente la caña de azúcar. Se encuentra ubicado a una hora de camino de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de dos años a la venta de jugos y sanguches en la ciudad de Cayaltí, posee un puesto situado en una esquina del centro de la ciudad, allí el ofrece los jugos que el mismo prepara a los transeúntes, este negocio le provee de ingresos que utiliza solventando sus gastos personales y ayudando a su familia.

Guillermo desea comprar una pequeña congeladora para empezar a vender jugos helados. Esta inversión le permitirá mejorar su negocio y captar mas clientes, por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Guillermo es un joven emprendedor y que lucha dia a dia para salir adelante. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo hasta lograr instalar una cafetería. Sus familiares y vecinos le consideran un joven honesto y responsable.
texts.en:
Guillermo is 18 years old, single and has no children. He lives with his parents and grandparents in Cayalti, a rural zone where it grows mostly sugar cane. It's located about one hour walking from the town of Chiclayo. He has been working for the past 2 years selling sandwiches and refreshments in Cayalti. He has a tent in a corner in the town centre and makes the juices himself.This business has helped him cover his life expenses and help his family. Guillermo would like to buy a small fridge so he could start selling cold beverages. This addition to his business will help with improving it and gain more clients. He is asking for a U$725 loan that will help him reach his goal. Guillermo is a hard working entrepeneur who fights every day to succeed. His biggest dream is to keep growing so one day he can open his own cafe. His relatives and neighbors consider him an honest and responsible young man.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a fridge to sell cold beverages

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario N. is from the village of Lower Lawan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 35 years old. Mario is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Mario owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling scrap metal, empty bottles, and other used products in the local community. Mario has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Mario is requesting a  loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more scrap metal to sell and as additional working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mario from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Pedro Celestino

texts.es:
el sr. Pedro M. se dedica a la produccion y venta de pan, tiene 15 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad, Pedro es muy dedicado a su trabajo, todos los dias se levanta a las 2 de la mañana para empezar su produccion y empacarlo para salir a las 5 de la mañana a venderlo y regresa a las 10 de la mañana a su casa. 
Pedro esta soltero.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de materiales para fabricar mas pan, ya que quiere expanderse en otras localidades.
su sueño es casarse y tener una bonita familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Pedro M. has been making and selling bread for 15 years. Pedro is very dedicaded to his work. Every day he gets up at 2 in the morning to begin his production and pack up the bread to leave at 5 in the morning to sell the bread. He returns to his house at 10 in the morning. Pedro is single. He will use the loan to buy materials to make more bread since he wants to expand to other neighborhoods. His dream is to get married and have a beautiful family.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Silvia Lorena

texts.es: doña Silvia C. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene un a pulperia en su casa de habitacion, vive en la aldea San Bernardo,  doña Silvia es madre de 3 hijos los cuales estan en la escuela de su  comunidad, es madre soltera. todos los dias se levantas a las 4 de la mañana para abrir su negocio y atender a sus clientes. El prestamo lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener su negocio bien surtido. las ganancias que le genere su negocio las necesita para salir adelante con sus hijos y darles una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Miss Silvia C. sells general consumption products – she has a general store in her house. She lives in the town of San Bernardo. Miss Silvia is a single mother of 3 children who are in the community school. Every day she gets up at 4 in the morning to open her business and attend to her customers. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise and therefore have a better supplied store. She needs earning she makes in her business to help her children get ahead and give them a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of beans, butter, rice, tortillas, coffee, margarine, oil, rice, sugar, bread, cookies, soda, matches, candles

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
la sra. Rosa Maria R. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pequeña pulperia en su casa de habitacion, tiene vaR. años de tener su negocio, el cual lo ha administrado muy bien.
Rosa vive en la aldea de San Bernardo, Rosa es viuda, hace 6 años que su esposo murio y vive solo con un hijo
varon y una sobrina, los cuales le ayudan con el negocio a atender sus clientes.
doña Rosa se levanta las 5 de la mañana todos los dias para atender el negocio, el cual queda enfrente de una escuela y muchos niños compran antes de entrar a clases.
el prestamo lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y asi surtir su negocio, las ganancias las necesita para salir adelante y darles una mejor calidad de vida a su hijo y a su sobrina.
texts.en:
Miss Rosa Maria R. sells general consumption products – she has a small general store in her house. She has had her business for several years, which she has run very well. Rosa lives in the town of San Bernardo. She is a widow, her husband died six years ago and she lives only with one son and one niece, who help her with the business by attending to her customers. Miss Rosa gets up at 5 in the morning every day to work in her store, which is located in front of a school and many children buy goods there before going to class. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise and therefore supply her store. She needs the income in order to get ahead and give a better quality of life to her son and her niece.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, salt, rice, sugar, bread, cookies, soda, juice, butter, oil, cornflour and wheat flour, tortillas, milk, soup, salsa, pasta

loans.name: Julia Del Socorro

texts.es:
la sra. Julia del Socorro R. se dedica a la produccion y venta de tortillas, tiene vaR. años de dedicarse a este tipo de actiividad, vive en la aldea de San Bernardo, todos los dias se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para empezar la produccion de las tortillas y luego salir a venderlas
Julia y su esposo han sido bien responsables con sus hijos, los han sacado adelante, Julia y su esposo solo viven con una hija que es la que le ayuda a hacer sus tortillas.  
doña Julia necesita incrementar su produccion ya que ahora tiene mas clientes y no se da abasto para cubrir con las necesidades de ellos.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas materiales para tener una mayor produccion.
las ganancias las necesita para cubrir con lso gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Miss Julia del Socorro R. makes and sells tortillas. She has been doing this for several years. She lives in the town of San Bernardo. Everyday she gets up at 5 in the morning to begin making tortillas and then she goes out to sell them. Julia and her husband have been very responsible with their children, whom they have provided for. Julia and her husband now live with one daughter who helps make the tortillas. Miss Julia needs to increase her production since now she has more customers and she does not have the supply to cover their needs. She will use the loan to buy more materials to increase her production. She needs the income in order to cover household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood, water, matches, and cornflour

loans.name: Lidia Marina

texts.es:
la sra. Lidia Marina S. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia ubicada en su casa de habitacion, su pulperia esta ubicada en el desvio que va para las playas de Cedeño.
la pulperia la abre todos los dias a las 5 de la mañana y la cierra a las 9 de la noche.
aparte de su negocio de pulperia Lidia se dedica a la crianza de gallinas y tiene un par de vacas.
el prestamo lo necesita para surtir bien su negocio ya que en estos momentos no tiene mucho producto en el.
las ganancias las necesita para salir adelante con su negocio y su familia.
texts.en:
Miss Lidia Marina S. sells general consumption products – she has a general store located in her house. Her general store is located on the route that heads to the beaches of Cedeño. She opens the stores every day at 5 in the morning and closes it at 9 at night. Besides her general store business, Lidia raises hens and has a pair of cows. She needs the loan to supply her business since currently she does not have very many products. She needs her income in order to get ahead with her business and support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Javier Alexander

texts.es:
Javier tiene 21 años de edad, es soltero y no tiene hijos, vive junto a su madre y hermana en el distrito de Zaña, un distrito conocido por sus costumbres y tradiciones afro – peruanas, se encuentra ubicado a cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Javier suele ganarse el sustento como obrero agrícola, el trabaja en una anexo pequeño ubicado al lado de la carretera que une los distritos de Zaña y Cayaltí. El estuvo ahorrando dinero y poco a poco logró instalar una bodega que es atendida por su madre. Estas actividades son las que le han brindado la posibilidad de sostenerse durante estos ultimos meses por lo que tratan de mantenerlas con mucho esfuerzo.

La bodega ha estado experimentando una creciente demanda por parte de sus clientes durante estos ultimos meses, por ello Javier ha creído conveniente ampliarla con la compra de mas artículos para ofrecerlos en venta, para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Javier es un joven trabajador y que siempre vela por el bienestar de su familia, su meta es seguir ofreciéndoles el sustento y llegar a mejorar su calidad de vida. En la zona donde vive sus vecinos le consideran una persona tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
Javier is 21, single, with no children. He lives with his mother and sister in the Zaña district, one known for its Afro-Peruvian customs and traditions. It is located forty-five minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Javier used to support himself as an agricultural worker. He worked in a small area located along the highway that runs between the Zaña and Cayalti districts. He had been saving money little by little and was able to open a grocery store that his mother manages. These activities are those which have offered them the possibility of self-sufficiency and for the last few months they are trying hard to keep them going. The store has experienced a growing demand by the customers in the last months. That is why Javier thinks it’s a good idea to expand by buying more articles to sell. To achieve this goal he is asking Edpyme Alternative for the first time for a loan of 1000 new sols. Javier is a young worker who always looks out for the welfare of his family. His goal is to continue give them financial support and to offer them a better quality of life. In the area where he lives his neighbors consider him a relaxed and responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise to expand his store

loans.name: Jose Jaime

texts.es:
José tiene 33 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa y a sus hijos en el sector San José del caserío Hornitos, una zona rural del distrito de Mórrope, caracterizado por tener a la mayoría de su población agrupada en pequeños caseríos que distan mucho uno del otro. El distrito pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y la zona se encuentra ubicada a una hora y quince minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Suele dedicarse a la comercialización de verduras desde hace mas de dos años, el compra verduras a los agricultores de la zona y las vende en la ciudad de Piura. Cuando la verdura escasea, se dedica al comercio de leña: el extrae leña del zapote, un arbol que crece en el distrito de Olmos, para venderla a los procesadores de yeso que utilizan la leña de este arbol para quemar el mineral antes de refinarlo.

Esta actividad siempre le genera ingresos, ya que en Mórrope se exrae yeso durante todo el año. José extrae su producto en base a diversos pedidos los cuales han venido aumentando en los ultimos meses, por este motivo ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de mas leña.

José es un padre que siempre vela por el bienestar se su familia, su mayor anhelo es verlos progresar poco a poco, hace poco construyó su casa propia y eso lo llena de orgullo. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de cancelar sus cuotas.
texts.en:
José is 33 years old, married, and lives with his wife and children in the San José sector of the village of Hornitos, a rural area in the district of Mórrope. The district is known for having the majority of its population clustered in small villages that are distant from one another. It is situated in Lambayeque Province and located an hour and fifteen minutes away from the city of Chiclayo.

José has been selling vegetables for more than two years. He buys his products from local farmers and sells them in the city of Piura. When vegetables are scarce, he sells firewood. The wood is extracted from sapodilla trees that grow in Olmos district and sold to gypsum processors for use in refining.

This business always generates income since gypsum mining takes place in Mórrope throughout the entire year. José purchases his product based on his orders which have been increasing in recent months. For this reason, he is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 2000 PEN so that he can invest in the purchase of more firewood.

José is a father who always looks out for the welfare of his family. His greatest wish is to see them gradually make progress. He recently built a house and is now full of pride. José previously worked with Edpyme Alternativa and has demonstrated that he is prompt and responsible when submitting his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase firewood to sell

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is married with two grown children, a son Ivan and a daughter Oksana. Lubov is a market entrepreneur from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. She has been in the women's footwear sales business for 13 years. Lubov started with just one little stall and expanded her business to several mobile vending locations in the region. She chose this type of inventory due to stable demand for it. Lubov can be characterized as a dynamic and ambitious person. She sets challenging goals and likes to see tasks accomplished. 

Currently Lubov has 10,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory. Her gross income amounts to 7,000 Grivnyas a month. Lubov is seeking an 8,000-Grivnya loan to increase assorted seasonal footwear merchandise for this summer. She is hoping to stay afloat in the competitive market despite all the gloomy economic prospects for the Ukrainian small business sector.

loans.use: To buy seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Silviya

texts.en:
Silviya is a small entrepreneur from Vinogradovo, Western Ukraine. She runs a food sales business in one of the wholesale markets in her hometown. Her vending kiosk is located right next to the market entrance, which has always been a busy spot crowded with potential customers. Silviya has been working as a private entrepreneur for seven years. Presently, she has about 60,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her income amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas.  

Silviya realizes the benefit her business has gained from available lending assistance. She is requesting a 12,000-Grivnya loan to increase her turnover capital and, as a result, her sales. Silviya realizes there are always needs to be met, especially if you have a family. She is willing to work hard to ensure a decent living for her family. One of her business goals is to open an additional vending location and continue developing her trade in the future.

loans.use: To increase her turnover capital

She loves working indoors instead of having to stand outside in the open-air market all day long. Victoria has a true enterprising spirit. She is willing to move on and never stop in her business progress. She is hoping to see her business succeed and bring her stable income for years to come.

Ildika has loyal customers who come to buy from her because they trust the quality of her inventory and enjoy her friendly and respectful service. She earns about $635 of net profit each month.

Ildika has used micro loans in the past and found them very instrumental in her business. This time Ildika is requesting a loan of 18,300 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventory. She would like to purchase additional clothing for the summer season so that she can increase her sales.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz G. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Luz is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Luz owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling souvenir island T-shirts and other clothing in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional plain T-shirts for printing. Luz is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Luz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene P. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old. Arlene is single. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for less than one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena sells women's shoes at the central market in Uzhgorod town. She has been in this business for ten years. Her income is 3,000 UAH per month.

Olena is the kind of person who, if she decides something, goes slowly but persistently until she reaches her goal. When she started this business, she  wanted to be economically independent and she has now reached this goal. Today, she has many regular clients and a stable business. Olena is a very friendly person and has good relationships with her neighbors at the market. 

Olena would like to borrow 6,400 UAH to purchase additional inventory.  She hopes to make greater profit and improve her living condition.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina, the married mother of one daughter, is an entrepreneur from Melitopol selling women's clothing in one of the local marketplaces. She started this business seven years ago, operating from a well-equipped and lit vending location and accruing a net profit of 5,500 Grivnyas a month from gross income of about 30,000 Grivnyas.

Now requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to increase assorted merchandise and receive additional income as a result, Irina is hoping to reinvest the generated income into further development of her trade. Irina can be characterized as a reliable borrower who always makes prompt payments of her loans. We believe the current loan will benefit her venture and ensure its stable growth in the years to come.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en:
Mr. K., 55, lives in Kompong Cham Province and earns a low income. He is a good and determined father who has tried to support his five children since they were very young. Now, four of his children are married and live on their own, while the fifth is single and attends school. Mr. Kouen is a widower.

To earn a living, Mr. Kouen does farm work. Every day in the late morning, he goes to the field next to his house where he plants various crops. He also raises a few pigs in a stall for additional income. Mr. K. is seeking a loan as working capital to invest in growing a better potato crop.

loans.use: To improve his potato crop.

loans.name: Sampaguita

texts.en:
At 51 years of age, Sampaguita S. is enjoying her career being a wife, a mother, and a businesswoman. Even though she is financially unable to consistently combat poverty and the challenge to supporting her family, Sampaguita has never seen a life happier than hers since her family supports one another through thick and thin. 

Her husband works hard in the field farming rice as a hired laborer. His small and sporadic income is remitted to Sampaguita, being the one in charge of the family budget. A large portion of it goes for the education of her two children in high school.  

Sampaguita really wants her children to graduate from college and have a better career in the future. She was frustrated when her eldest child stopped schooling after elementary. However, she had no choice then because she didn’t have enough income to support her education. With that, Sampaguita learned a lesson. She realized she has to have her own business and supplement the income of her husband. 

This realization led her to ASHI in 2002. Since then she has been receiving loans and has able to put up her own small “sari-sari” (variety) store, selling a small volume of various grocery items, foodstuffs, beverages and other commodities. People would tend to buy things they need from her than going to market and spending carfare. Therefore, Samapguita’s store has acquired a lot of customers from around their village. 

Proceeds from this business have somehow made life easy and enjoyable for her family, especially her children. Because she sees the potential of improving their standard of living once her business has grown, as well as its profit, Sampaguita is applying for a much larger  loan amount from ASHI. Her husband supports her decision for this because he sees his wife enjoying her career running her own business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages for her "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Perly

texts.en:
Perly J.'s main source of income comes from selling Ready-to-Wear and slightly used clothing in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. Perly has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2010, Perly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Perly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Perly is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offerings. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

This is her third loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner in Cambodia. V. appears in the photograph with her husband.

texts.en:
Son R. is 47 years old and is a resident of Kompong Cham Province where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She grows rice and vegetable crops, which she plants twice a year. She is a good mother to her two children who are students. The children assist with their parent’s trade when they are free from school. Son R. is married to Kea, age 41, who works on the farm that is on the right of the photo. 

Crop growing is Son R.’s main source of income to sustain her family. To earn more income, Son R. is applying for a loan so she can plant potatoes.

loans.name: Subdra

texts.en:
Ms. Subdra K. has two sons and one daughter. Her older son is in grade 8, her younger son is in grade 2, and her daughter is in grade 4. Her husband, Mr. Surendra K., works in a grocery store.

Mrs. Subdra already owns a cow and she has been selling milk in the area. In Nepal pure, fresh cow’s milk is highly valued for its nutrition. Subdra lives in a growing neighborhood and in that area the demand for milk is increasing. She carries her milk containers door to door to sell the milk every morning and evening.  Because of the rising demand, she wants to buy another cow to increase her production.  Radika plans to purchase a jersey cow, which produces more milk than normal cows.

loans.use: To buys a cow

texts.en: Poi C. is 45 years old. He lives with his wife and six of his children in the Battambang province. He is a policeman with a salary of US$90 per month. His wife stays at home to look after the children and to raise pigs for additional income. On average, she makes US$1 a day. All of the children are in school. Poi C. is asking for a loan of US$1200 for his wife to raise more pigs. The photo shows Poi C. with his wife at their home.

loans.name: Radha

texts.en:
Mrs. Radha L. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishepati, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband, Mr. Kedar, and her two daughters. Her husband works in a steel shop. Her older daughter is studying in grade 10 and the younger daughter is studying in grade 8.

Mrs. Radha opened a grocery shop two years ago to improve her family's standard of living.  Their condition is not good so they can't provide a better education for their daughters because in Nepal the cost of education is very high. To overcome this problem, she opened a grocery shop. 
Due to a lack of funds, she can’t buy goods for her shop. So she is asking for a loan to buy goods like rice, dhal, noodles, etc. 

She needs to spend her income to provide a better education for her daughters and wishes to help her husband improve the family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her store

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn A. has been an ASHI member since 2005. During her almost five years in ASHI, she has shown herself to be industrious and determined to make her dreams come true. Her family is very thankful that she has an opportunity to improve their standard of living through the proceeds of her variety store business that she has established with the support of the loans she has requested from ASHI.The variety store business has brought happiness to Evelyn’s family, and especially to her. Because of its profits, she has been able to send her children to school. Being a good mother, Evelyn’s dreams are always for her children and family. She always wanted to support her children to have a brighter tomorrow and a decent life.

With that in mind, Evelyn is requesting a loan from ASHI amounting to 30,000 Php to purchase more supplies for her store in order to attract more customers. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for inventory of groceries for her store. She is very determined and disciplined to use the money which is lent to her. This would not only provide her with happiness in life, but would also make her business grow and make more profit, which will allow her to support the educational needs of her four children until they graduate from college.

Evelyn is hopeful that her business will grow into a full-fledged mini-grocery store and that someday she will have branches in nearby villages. One of her aspirations is to be able to build a house that is durable and spacious.

Her long-term goals are to purchase a new 'jeepney' (public transport vehicle) and tricycle (three-wheeled motorcycle) so she can expand her business to other surrounding neighborhoods.   By owning her own transportation, Evelyn will save time and money in purchasing a greater variety of inventory.  With her hard work, Evelyn is hopeful that her business ventures will continue to grow and improve the overall quality of living for her family.

loans.use: To pay for groceries for her sari-sari (variety) store

texts.en:

Her daughter is studying in grade 12 and her son is studying in grade 9. Mrs. Deepa is a center chief in her group. Being a center chief means she has taken responsibility for all her center members.

Mrs. Deepa and her husband, Mr. Ramesh K., opened their veterinary pharmacy five years ago. They sell different types of domestic-animal medicine in their shop. They both contribute equally in their shop because they don’t have any other jobs. 

Mrs. Deepa already has taken her second loan with Kiva and has cleared it. With the previous loan she was able to buy various medicines for her shop. Now Mrs. Deepa is requesting Rs 30000.00 to expand her business and buy more necessary medicines for her shop.

loans.use: To invest in her shop

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ear

texts.en: Ear E. is 38 years old and sells flowers in the Takeo province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$5 every day. She has five children, two of which are in school and three who are employed with different jobs. She has requested a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children so that her child can operate a moto-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a moto-taxi.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. L. is an older woman whose husband appears in the left of the photo. She is the mother of five school-aged kids, who are all dependent on her. L. has been engaged in a business selling soft drinks for years. Additionally, she sells some snack foods at night for the people who come across her street. She has a life partner in her husband who owns a car to deliver the produce for her to sell. Sometimes he uses his car to pick up merchandise which belongs to other merchantmen, for which he charges a fee. 

Mrs. L. says the pig-raising business is a profitable one and she wants to invest in this line for extra profit. Because Mrs. L. doesn’t have capital, she decided to request a loan of US$1,200 from Kiva’s project partner, HKL. She will be using her first loan to purchase 10 piglets and some pig foods to begin breeding in a stall she has already built behind her house. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will mend an old vehicle which breaks down often.

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Emprendedoras De Casa Huerta Group

texts.es:
Nelly N. es integrante D. L. alcancía comunal "Emprendedoras D. Casa Huerta", tiene 48 años y es casada con el padre D. sus 4 hijos.
ElL.  trabajaba en un taller D. costura realizando estampados D. polos ubicado cerca D. su  domicilio,  al transcurrir el tiempo Nelly decidió trabajar en gamarra (Centro Comercial  muy transcurrido en el  sector D. lima), en L. actualidad realiza  l operación D. costura estampados y remalle D. ropa.
Este actual préstamo lo invertirá en L. compra D. materiales para hacer  colchas y cubre cama para su venta.
Uno D. sus anhelos es realizar L. compra D. una maquina D. coser y lo mas importante apoyar a sus hijos en todo
texts.en:
Nelly N. is a member of the village bank Emprendedoras D. Casa Huerta. She is 48 years old, married, with 4 children. She works in a sewing shop near her home where she does screen printing on shirts. As time went by, Nelly decided to work in Gamarra (a popular commercial center in eastern Lima), and now has a business selling screen-printed clothing and tailoring. She will use this loan to buy materials to make bedspreads and bedcovers to sell. One of her desires is to buy a sewing machine. Most important to her is helping her children in everything.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Powell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to make bedcovers and bedspreads

loans.name: Gil

texts.en:
Gil B., 39, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Happily married to Regina B., Gil makes sure that he earns enough money so that his family can have a better life. He has been into managing a retail store for quite some time now.

Gil has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. He regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays his weekly dues consistently. His good repayment performance with his previous loans means he was able to borrow eight times in CCT’s Cooperative. He is consistent in paying his dues because he has used the money he borrowed to expand and improve his business. 

To ensure the success of his business, Gil has applied for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to the expanding businesses by buying additional stocks to be incorporated into his current product inventory.

Gil dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can attain the quality of life he desires. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of inventory

loans.name: Ronnah

texts.en:
Despite being poor and having limited access to a lot of opportunities to improve herself and life, having been married and becoming  a mother to her two-year-old only child at an early age, Ronnah felt happy and blessed when she became a member of ASHI in 2008. Aside from being able to receive a loan and finance her own business, she is happy about the opportunity of meeting other women and mothers in their village and listening to their sharing of experiences in growing a business and how they balance their own career being a wife and mother at the same time as a business woman. Aside from her family, members of ASHI in the center she belongs to are her inspiration to become a better and more productive woman.

Ronnah wants to support the education of her only child until she graduates from college. Therefore she has started growing her small “sari-sari” store now while Jorin Mikaela, her daughter, is still young. “Sari-sari” means a small volume of various grocery items, foodstuffs, beverages and other commodities. People tend to buy things they need from here than going to market and spending carfare. Profit gained from this business is Ronnah’s means of supporting the needs of her family. She also wants to start up a hog fattening and hog-raising business in their backyard through the loan she requests, so that her father whom she supports will have his own means to earn an income.

Looking forward to her small “sari-sari” store turning into a big grocery store which sells complete commodities through loans she can access through ASHI, Ronnah hopes to build up a savings fund to finance her dream of building their own house and living independently from her father.

loans.use: To purchase a large volume of various grocery items, etc.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina Y. is a hardworking, married woman who sells orchids to earn a living. She’s been selling orchids to the people in her village for ten years.  Cristina belongs to a group of young entrepreneurs where she saves her money and has secured capital from ASHI. She appreciates that the organization has helped her improve her business, hence her better living standards. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy orchid seeds and  more orchids to sell.  She hopes to buy more orchids in the future for better output. She sees herself venturing into the flower shop business in the next five years.  Cristina is hoping that her envisioned business will help her in supporting the financial needs of her two children so that they are able to graduate from college. By then, Cristina thinks their lives will be changed and she will have her dreams achieved.

loans.use: to buy more orchid seeds and orchids to sell

loans.name: Las Positivas Group

texts.es:
Guillermina Verástegui de 48 años de edad casada con el padre de sus 3 hijos 2 de ellos aun menores de edad  es integrante de la Alcancía Comunal Las Positivas. Grupo que cursa su 1er ciclo.
Guillermina se dedicaba a la venta de comida pero al  transcurrir el tiempo con el ahorro que contaba lo decidió invertir en la compra de una carreta de golosinas hoy vende todo lo que es golosinas gaseosas en la puerta de un colegio.
Su actual préstamo lo invertirá en su mercadería y surtirlo con la variedad de golosinas que pueda ofrecer 
Ella tiene planes como en la compra de una carreta mas amplia  para así de esa manera ofrecer no solo golosinas si no también comida, y por su puesto  en ofrecer a sus dos menores hijos apoyo en sus estudios.
texts.en:
Guillermina Verástegui, 48, is married to the father of her 3 children, 2 of whom are grown. She is a member of the communal bank group Las Positivas, a group entering its first loan cycle. Guillermina once sold food, but as time passed she saved up money and decided to invest in a candy cart. Today she sells every kind of soft candy in front of a school. She will invest her loan in buying merchandise and stocking it with a variety of goodies. She has plans, such as buying a wider cart in order to offer not only candy but also food. Of course, she will also invest in offering her two younger children support with their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: EN LA COMPRA DE SU MERCADERIA COMO GOLOSINAS Y GASEOSA

loans.name: Sarm

texts.en: Sarm N., 43, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. N. has requested a loan of USD $800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Ren

texts.en:
Mr. Ren V., 44, is a hard-working man who resides in Kompong Cham, a province of Cambodia. He lives with six unmarried children, while another one is now married and lives independently.

Ren V. owns a small business for which the main operation is to grow a variety of crops on a piece of land he owns. By doing this he is able to earn some suitable money to contribute to any expenses for his family.

His wife is a good manager who assists him in the field. Ren V. has other farmland which is covered by thick grass in which he can’t plant a crop. Thus, he is requesting a loan to clean up the land where he will grow potato crops. Mr. Ren V., his wife, and his children are pictured.

loans.use: To clean up farmland.

loans.name: Simeona

texts.en:
Simeona B., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs.  Happily married to Danilo B., a farmer, they are blessed with 5 children.  Simeona makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been into managing an ornamental and flower raising business while also operating a tricycle unit for seven years now.

Simeona has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than five years now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow six times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Simeona would like to apply for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding businesses for buying additional ornamental plants, needed materials and also buying spare parts for the maintenance of their own tricycle unit.

Simeona dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy an additional home lot for their children to settle on someday.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying additional ornamentals, fertilizers, needed materials and spare parts for the maintenance of tricycle unit.

loans.name: Tum

texts.en:
Tum H., 34, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a food seller with an income of 8 USD per day. Her husband helps his wife in the business.

H. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s studies.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Tarpat's Group

texts.en:
Tarpat U. is the leader of this group. She is 50, married, and her husband works as a carpenter. They have seven children, most of whom are married and live separately with their families. Their younger son serves in the armed forces and their younger daughter studies at school. When the children have time, they help Tarpat with housework.

Tarpat grows raspberries and her husband also takes orders to produce the Kyrgyz national instrument – komuz. In this way they make 5,000 soms (approximately 110 USD) a month. With the money received from the loan, Tarpat will purchase a cow for breeding. In the future she plans to repair her house and save some money to contribute to her younger son's wedding.

Anarkan K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37, divorced, and has a four-year-old son. After graduating from school, Anarkan started to work and has been working as a hospital janitor for seventeen years. She wants to obtain a loan because she needs money for personal needs.

Avaz T., 56, is a widow, and has six children. All of them, except her youngest son, are married and live separately. Four years ago Avaz's son began as an apprentice to a handyman and thus now he is able to do handiwork on his own. Now he earns 4,100 soms (approximately 90 USD) a month. Avaz needs a loan to purchase fertilizers and different seeds for farming.

Musa K. is 70 and is married. His wife is a pensioner. There are six children in their family and all the children, except his youngest son, are married and live separately. Musa with his son are engaged in welding and carpentry and they have been doing this for nine years. In this way Musa makes 5,000 soms a month. With the money received from the loan, he will purchase fertilizers and new kinds of seeds, needed for farming.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for breeding

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en:
Meoun L., 34, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean Temples.

L. sells Cambodian noodles for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband sells ice-cream, earning an income of USD 7 per day. She is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase more ice-cream boxes to expand her husband’s business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, L. would like to use any additional profits to support her children’s study.

loans.use: To buy more ice-cream boxes for her husband's ice-cream business

loans.name: Ma. Rizza

texts.en:
Ma. Rizza B. is a hard working entrepreneur determined to improve her family's standard of living. As a busy entrepreneur, she has been running a sari-sari (variety) store for almost two years.  Building her business, Ma. Rizza would like to receive a loan of 15,000 PHP to increase the inventory of goods sold in her sari-sari store.  She is planning to purchase additional products such as cases of soft drinks, sugar, cooking oil, liquors, salt, shampoo, and other supplies.  Ma. Rizza believes that offering a wide assortment of goods to customers will increase traffic to her store and maintain customer loyalty in the village.

Her long term goals are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her store, and start a savings account for her children’s future to secure for them a decent life.  Through hard work and determination, Ma. Rizza is focused on improving her quality of life with the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as cases of soft drinks, sugar, cooking oil, liquors, salt, shampoo, and other supplies.

loans.name: 03.1.9 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en: Hai C. T. (43) is a 46-year-old female living in the town of T. Hoa. She is the group leader of this three-member group loan offered by T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 03.1.9 Nam Ngan (02,03,1.9 Nam Ngạn). Hai is married and has two adult children. She owns and operates a food stall, selling pork products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month. In 2009, Hai joined T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,963,500 VND from T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Hai is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will again be used to invest in expanding her business. The loan will be her 2nd from T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. N. T. T. Thuy (44) is a 21-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 2. N. T. T. (45) is a 30-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. About T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the T. Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Hai C. T. (43) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố T. Hoa. Hai là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 03,1,9 Nam Ngan (02,03,1.9 Nam Ngạn). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên T. nhập, mà nguồn T. nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ thịt heo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Hai thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Hai kiếm được khoảng 3,000,000 VND. Vào 2009, Hai đã tham gia T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Hai đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,963,500 VND từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. T. T. Thuy (44) là 21 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 2. N. T. T. (45) là 30 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. Về T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo T. Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh T. Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Horn H., 63, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean Temples.

H. and her husband are farmers, growing rice for an income of USD 6 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more cows to plow the rice fields. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, H. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy more cows to plow the rice fields

loans.name: Brenda Lee

texts.en:
Brenda Lee B., 35, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is happily married to Victor Benjamin B. Jr. and they are blessed with one child. Brenda Lee makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing a small variety store for quite some time now.

Brenda Lee has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for almost six years. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow thirteen times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

To ensure the success of her business, Brenda Lee would like to apply for a loan of 24,000 PHP. This will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses by buying additional products to be incorporated into her current inventory.

Brenda Lee dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education and be able to purchase their own house and lot.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additonal products to be incorporated into her current inventory

loans.name: Poy

texts.en: Poy S., 41, is married and lives with her husband and five children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. She is a cleaner and a chef earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase wood to repair the house and a bicycle for her children to commute to school. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy wood to repair the house and a bicycle for her children to go to school

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma A., 37, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Happily married to Edito A., a driver, they are blessed with two children. Vilma makes sure that she helps her husband's earnings so that their family can have a better life. She has been in the fruit vending business for quite some time now.

Vilma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than six years. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means that she has been able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Vilma would like to apply for a loan of 10,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital in the expanding business by buying different kinds of fruit to sell.

Vilma dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of fruit to sell

loans.name: Brak

texts.en:
Brak M., 44, is married and lives with four of her children in the Takeo province. She works as a farmer, making US$3 each day, while her husband also does some farming and works as a construction worker, making about US$3 each day as well. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians.

In light of these difficult times, she is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase more farmland on which to grow more rice. She sees this new rice field as a good economic investment and will use it to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase farmland for rice growing

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
Rosaline C., 34, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Happily married to Arnel C., a tricycle driver and operator, they are blessed with four children. Rosaline makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing a variety store while operating a tricycle for 16 years.

Rosaline has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for almost six years now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means that she has been able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Rosaline would like to apply for a loan of 19,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for the expanding businesses and will buy additional items to be added to her current product inventory.

Rosaline dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional items to add to her current product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Saidmahmad

texts.ru: Тагоев Саидмахмад проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Образование высшее. Более 25 лет работал госслужащим в Хукумате района. Сейчас клиент занимается растениеводством. Он в основном сеет пшеницу и овощи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Saidmahmad T. lives in the Yavan region. He is 50 years old. He is married and has one child. He has high education. Saidmahmad has worked as a government worker in the Khukumat region for more than 25 years. Right now he does agriculture. He mainly grows wheat and vegetables. He has been doing this business for more than six years. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abarihamwe Investments, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
N. Winnie is a hardworking, and an ever-optimistic, 32-year-old married mother of three, aged between 5 and 6 years.

Winnie operates a modest retail business in Ntungamo town dealing in general merchandise like soap, matches, soft drinks, beer, salt, sugar and much more. With a business longevity of five years, she has managed to significantly sustain and improve on her family’s welfare.

To all appearances, Winnie’s future business prospects look rosy. With close to 100,000 Ugandan shillings coming in every week out of her business, she envisions an even greater profit margin once she can get this loan as she anticipates being in a position to buy more merchandise for her retail shop business. This will enable her to expand and also be able to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her business

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina B. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 46 years old, is widowed and has six adult children. To make a living, Antonina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Antonina has been engaged in her business for over 28 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Antonina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Antonina is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the eighth loan she has taken out from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Cecilia Del Carmen

texts.es: Cecilia del Carmen A. D. R. D. 53 años D. edad, una señora muy alegre y amable, la cual posee muy buenas referencias por parte D. sus amigos y vecinos, ya que se destaca por ser alguien responsable y respetuosa, la cual siempre ha trabajado junto a su esposo por sacar adelante su hogar y a sus dos hijos, los cuales a pesar que son mayores D. edad, se dedican a estudiar en la universidad, y aún no poseen trabajo, por lo que dependen D. sus padres. El esposo D. Cecilia se dedica a la venta D. carne D. res, y así mismo a una venta D. productos varios como shampoo, pasta dental y otros más. Cecilia posee una tienda en la cual comercializa todo tipo D. productos D. primera necesidad, en la cual ha trabajado durante años para poder surtirla y D. esta forma obtener todos los beneficios posibles D. su negocio. Es por esto que Cecilia, solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con los recursos necesarios para comprar muchos más productos comestibles como: pan, golosinas, huevos y otros más, D. los cuales son los que más se venden, así mismo comprar productos D. primera necesidad para el hogar. Todo esto es con el fin D. mejorar las ganancias obtenidas por la tienda y así poseer un negocio más rentable, el cual se encuentra ubicado en su casa D. habitación en el departamento D. Sonsonate.
texts.en:
Cecilia del Carmen A. D. R. is a cheerful and friendly woman who is 53 years old and has excellent references from her friends and neighbors. They consider her to be someone who is responsible and respectful. She and husband work together to move their household forward and support their two children. Even though they are adults, one child is a university student while the other does not have a job, so they are still dependent on their parents. Cecilia’s husband sells beef while she sells various products such as shampoo, toothpaste, and other items. She has a store where she sells all types of basic necessities. Throughout the year, she works to keep her store stocked so that she can reap all the possible benefits from her business.

In this instance, Cecilia is requesting a loan so that she can have the necessary resources to buy more food products such as bread, candy, eggs, and other items that sell very well. She will also buy products that are basic necessities in the home. Everything she does is with the purpose of improving her earnings so that her business will be more profitable. She manages her store out of her house, which is located in the Department of Sonsonate.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Feruzahan's Group

texts.en:
Feruzahan E. is the leader of the group. She is married and her husband has gone to Russia to work.  Her one son was born in 2003 and is currently in kindergarten. For a living, Feruzahan sells cigarettes, drinks and chocolate in a kiosk. She set up shop in a bustling part of town six years ago. Feruzahan’s initial investment for the kiosk was 3000 soms ($62.28) and now she makes 15401 soms ($335.16) per month. With money from the loan, she plans to purchase a variety of soda drinks for the summer season. Her wish is to increase turnover and open a new shop.

Zharkynai M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 29 and is divorced. She makes a living by growing and selling agricultural products. Fortunately, her brother and his wife help her with her work. Seven years ago, she began to cultivate the land with 300 kg of seed potatoes. Today she wants to use her loan to buy fertilizer and more seed potatoes. Zharkynai dreams of buying a house in the city.

Orozmamat M. is 40 years old, is divorced and has two daughters who are currently at school. Orozmamat collects and resells plastic and glass in villages and then sells them in the district center. Orozmamat started this business three years ago with a 2000 som ($43.52) investment, today he makes 7450 soms ($162.13) per month. He plans to use the loan to increase his turnover so that he can make repairs to his house as well as purchase livestock.

Gulzina T. is 25 and married. Gulzina and her husband are both farmers. She breeds, fattens and then sells the cattle. Gulzina learned this trade from her parents—the tradition has been passed on. She makes a monthly profit of 2133 soms ($46.42) and with the loan she plans to purchase more livestock to improve her living conditions.

--- Where did this loan come from? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of soda drinks for the summer season
